title: Slow syncing
body:
#### System information

Geth version: 1.7.2-stable-1db4ecdc
OS & Version: Windows 2008 R2
Commit hash : (if `develop`)

INFO [10-26|09:14:27] Imported new chain segment               blocks=3 txs=419
INFO [10-26|09:14:40] Imported new chain segment               blocks=4 txs=149
INFO [10-26|09:14:48] Imported new chain segment               blocks=4 txs=237
INFO [10-26|09:15:00] Imported new chain segment               blocks=4 txs=604
INFO [10-26|09:15:09] Imported new chain segment               blocks=4 txs=316
INFO [10-26|09:15:18] Imported new chain segment               blocks=3 txs=213
INFO [10-26|09:15:26] Imported new chain segment               blocks=4 txs=301
INFO [10-26|09:15:40] Imported new chain segment               blocks=3 txs=271
INFO [10-26|09:15:49] Imported new chain segment               blocks=2 txs=117
> eth.blockNumber
4387214
> eth.syncing
{
  currentBlock: 4387214,
  highestBlock: 4430115,
  .... }

#### Expected behaviour
geth to be syncing faster

#### Actual behaviour
very slow syncing.
The difference between highest and current block is 4430115-4387214 = 42091.
At the rate of about 12 seconds per 4 blocks, 42091 blocks is going to take 31568 seconds, which is about 9 hours. 

INFO [10-26|20:46:30] Imported new chain segment               blocks=4  txs=306  mgas=12.033
INFO [10-26|20:46:39] Imported new chain segment               blocks=5  txs=256  mgas=13.753
INFO [10-26|20:46:48] Imported new chain segment               blocks=9  txs=889  mgas=25.832
INFO [10-26|20:46:58] Imported new chain segment               blocks=4  txs=383  mgas=16.984
> eth.syncing
{
  currentBlock: 4397623,
  highestBlock: 4431557,
  knownStates: 0,
  pulledStates: 0,
  startingBlock: 4390564

11 hours later: It's been about 11 hours since I wrote the above, and the currentBlock is: 4397623, and the syncing is still not done.
I have the feeling that the syncing is slower than realtime. I've been running it for days (although not 24/7) but I'm still behind the network.

Seems you need a high performance machine to get in sync, because new blocks are coming faster than they can be processed.
I'm observing this right now on my server running geth with an 8-core CPU, which is under full load and shows high IO usage. After fast syncing it's full syncing now, but not coming closer to an end!

Would be nice if fast sync would sync fast till the end and not auto disables 1024 blocks pre end. So on lowend machines you would get in sync, which you'll never get with the actual behaviour.

i've been trying to sync non-stop for the past weeks on a 50 MBit internet connection but it's ridiculously slow:
```
INFO [12-18|08:00:00] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=169 mgas=6.680  elapsed=1m13.262s mgasps=0.091 number=4433178 hash=2decc6…0a6311
INFO [12-18|08:00:57] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=159 mgas=6.677  elapsed=57.248s   mgasps=0.117 number=4433179 hash=6bee2a…0bb69a
INFO [12-18|08:01:52] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=166 mgas=6.690  elapsed=54.621s   mgasps=0.122 number=4433180 hash=6315e8…f3581f
INFO [12-18|08:02:25] Imported new chain segment               blocks=2 txs=112 mgas=7.235  elapsed=32.529s   mgasps=0.222 number=4433182 hash=286f38…08010b
INFO [12-18|08:02:42] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=97  mgas=6.700  elapsed=17.796s   mgasps=0.377 number=4433183 hash=db8162…0a19b5
INFO [12-18|08:03:46] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=143 mgas=6.701  elapsed=1m3.907s  mgasps=0.105 number=4433184 hash=df5877…8e1092
INFO [12-18|08:04:02] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=58  mgas=1.928  elapsed=15.832s   mgasps=0.122 number=4433185 hash=f2b61d…4c5700
INFO [12-18|08:04:33] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=99  mgas=6.700  elapsed=31.041s   mgasps=0.216 number=4433186 hash=558e92…f95f28
INFO [12-18|08:04:53] Imported new chain segment               blocks=2 txs=63  mgas=2.308  elapsed=19.799s   mgasps=0.117 number=4433188 hash=8b7447…abd3a4
INFO [12-18|08:05:27] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=111 mgas=6.708  elapsed=34.094s   mgasps=0.197 number=4433189 hash=143dc5…fd1eab
```
at this rate I will never catch up synching because new blocks are created faster than I can download them.
I'm also running Ethereum wallet for Days and I'm still not up to date. I'm running Linux Mint with Mist (https://github.com/ethereum/mist/releases).
I am also running with geth my sync current block is 10000 behind from highest Block. can anybody give a solution for this. Any small help will be appreciable.
This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has not had recent activity. It will be closed if no further activity occurs. Thank you for your contributions.

Hi,
Please advice in case I should open a new case.

I am having same/similar issue, moreover my node was synced to latest block few days ego.

My node spec:
raspberry pi: Raspberry Pi 4 Model B 
-- Memory: 8GB
-- Memory card: 64GB
Drive: | ssd 1TB   
geth version: 1.9.22-unstable  
Output for `sudo tail -f /var/log/syslog`

This has been the case for the last few days and to be noticed that the age is actually increasing. 
It seems to me the peer count tried number is very low: rarely is above 6. If I remember well I use to see around 300 or more.

```
Dec 16 16:20:50 geth geth[1399]: INFO [12-16|16:20:50.268] Looking for peers                        peercount=0 tried=4 static=0

Dec 16 16:21:34 geth geth[1399]: INFO [12-16|16:21:34.097] Downloader queue stats                   receiptTasks=0 blockTasks=2099 itemSize=35.68KiB throttle=1837
Dec 16 16:21:34 geth geth[1399]: WARN [12-16|16:21:34.097] Synchronisation failed, dropping peer    peer=2869528bf8571a1f err="retrieved hash chain is invalid: no peers to keep download active"
Dec 16 16:21:40 geth geth[1399]: INFO [12-16|16:21:40.308] Looking for peers                        peercount=0 tried=5 static=0
```
It would be great to have some help.
Thank you
